title: Reframing SI Results in Academic Context

benchmark.paper: Gu, Kelly & Xiu (2020) "Empirical Asset Pricing via Machine Learning"
benchmark.note: Considered excellent and highly cited (3000+ citations)

r_squared_context.comparison: Our R² of 1.3% is 3.25x higher than the benchmark
r_squared_context.conclusion: Our effect size is competitive by academic finance standards

causal_disclaimer.what_we_show: Correlation between SI and market features
causal_disclaimer.what_we_dont_claim: Causal relationship from SI to returns
causal_disclaimer.honest_statement: We establish statistical association, not causation. SI reflects agent adaptation to market conditions. Whether SI causes future outcomes requires instrumental variable analysis beyond this paper's scope.
causal_disclaimer.causal_dag:
Competition → Agent Affinities → SI ↔ Market Conditions → Future Returns
(SI is endogenous; correlation established, causation not claimed)

practical_limitations.standalone_trading: NO - R² too low for primary signal
practical_limitations.supplementary_use: YES - Confirms other signals, factor timing
practical_limitations.recommendation: Use SI as supplementary indicator, not replacement for existing strategies. Most valuable for conditioning factor exposure.

theorem_framing.claim: We apply known results (Hedge algorithm) to financial agents
theorem_framing.novelty: Empirical - showing emergence in real data, not theoretical innovation
theorem_framing.honest_statement: The regret bound O(√T) is a standard result from online learning. Our contribution is empirical validation that this mechanism produces measurable SI in real financial markets.

revised_contribution_statement: 1. First empirical measurement of SI in multi-agent trading systems
5. Honest reporting of negative results (regime conditioning failed)
